title.value: Estimating Social Influence from Observational Data
title.justification: The title directly extracted from the paper's header and emphasized multiple times throughout the document.
title.quote: Estimating Social Influence from Observational Data

extractions.description: This paper addresses the challenges of estimating social influence from observational data by introducing the Poisson Influence Factorization (PIF) method. It formalizes social influence as a causal effect and provides a methodology to infer it despite unobserved confounders. PIF is tested using semi-synthetic simulations and real data from Last.fm, showing it can accurately determine social influence.

type.justification: The paper conducts empirical studies using semi-synthetic simulations and real-world data from Last.fm to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method (PIF) in estimating social influence.
type.quote: We empirically study PIF with semi-synthetic and real data from Last.fm, and conduct a sensitivity analysis.

name.justification: The paper primarily concerns estimating causal effects regarding social influence within social networks, a typical problem setting within causal inference studies.
name.quote: This paper is about analyzing social network data to estimate social influence, the effect that its members have on each other.

name.justification: The research involves developing an algorithm (PIF) to handle social influence estimation, which falls under the machine learning domain.
name.quote: We develop Poisson Influence Factorization (PIF), a new method for estimating social influence.

name.justification: The methodology employs probabilistic models like Poisson factorization for estimating social influence, indicating the paper's engagement with probabilistic modeling.
name.quote: PIF fits probabilistic factor models to networks and behavior data to infer variables.

name.justification: PIF is the primary methodological contribution of the paper designed to estimate social influence from observational data.
name.quote: We develop Poisson Influence Factorization (PIF), a new method for estimating social influence.

is_contributed.justification: The paper introduces PIF as its main methodological contribution to the field of causal inference for social networks.
is_contributed.quote: The third contribution is the PIF algorithm for estimating social influence from observed networks.

is_executed.justification: The paper describes empirical results obtained by executing the PIF model on both semi-synthetic and real-world data to estimate social influence.
is_executed.quote: We empirically study PIF with semi-synthetic and real data from Last.fm.

is_compared.justification: PIF is compared against other methods to evaluate its accuracy in estimating social influence.
is_compared.quote: We find that PIF estimates social influence most accurately compared to related methods.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper discusses theoretical foundations related to the confounding factors in causal inference, which PIF builds on.
referenced_paper_title.quote: In using latent variable models to estimate variables that help causal inference, PIF adapts and extends ideas from Wang and Blei (2019a); Shalizi and McFowland III (2016).

name.justification: Used as real-world data to empirically validate the PIF method.
name.quote: We empirically study PIF with semi-synthetic and real data from Last.fm.

referenced_paper_title.value: Split-door criterion for causal identification: Automatic search for natural experiments
referenced_paper_title.justification: Provides methodological background relevant to empirical studies, specifically dealing with causal identification.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Amit Sharma, Jake M Hofman, and Duncan J Watts. Split-door criterion for causal identification: Automatic search for natural experiments.
